chapter.title: The Flow editor tab
chapter.para: To create a Flow, you can follow the instructions of .

tip.para: Instead of buttons from the toolbar, try using context menus. To do so, right-click on a program you have added. Notice that many command can be accessed through this menu. For certain cases, this method is easier and faster than using command buttons.

section.title: Assembling the Flow
section.para: In GêBR, a Flow is a sequence of operations defined by you. These operations, also called the Flow's programsProgram, are organized into the following categories according to their purpose:

listitem.para: Gain, NMO, Stack and Standard Processes

section.para: To create a Flow, you must select and order programs from the above categories. Let us see how this is done:

step.para: In the tab Projects and Lines, check that you have selected a Line.

Now click on the tab Flows, then left-click on
.

The dialog box Flow "New Flow" Properties will appear, fill in a title for this Flow (for example, My First Flow). You can also give a brief description of the Flow, the author and an e-mail for contact. If you are done filling in this Flows properties click on OK.
Now select the tab Flow Editor. On the right side it will be shown a list with several menus. Choose one of them and include it in your Flow with a double-click.
If you need a specific order to the selected programs of your flow, you just need to drag and drop the desired programs.

mediaobject.caption: In the Flow editor, on the right side of the main window you will see the MenusMenu box. From this box you can add programs to your Flow, which will appear in the Flow sequence box on the left side of the main window.

step.para:
To enable a program of your Flow, you will have to right-click over it and select the Configured option. The icon will change from
to
.

mediaobject.caption: To enable a program, select the Configured option.

tip.para:
If you want to change all programs, or a few, to the configured state simultaneously, select them by using
Ctrl Click . Then right-click on one of the selected programs, choose the option Configured from the menu that appeared. All the programs that were selected will be altered to the state
.

important.para:
To run a Flow all the programs listed in the Flow Sequence box must be Configured (
). Otherwise the Flow will not be executed as expected.

The state of a Flow, or a set of Flows, can be changed by using the hotkey Spacebar, which alters the state of the selected programs in the order Not configured, Disabled and Configured. The meaning of these states will be further described later on.

section.para:
Your Flow is ready to be executed. Click on
to do it.

After you have created a Flow, it will be visible on the left side of the main window when the Flows tab is selected. The Details box, found on the right side of the main window, shows information on the selected Flow .
section.tip: There is no limit on the number of Flows you can have in one Line.

tip.para: You can alter the position of the Flow in the list by dragging the Flow with the mouse to the desired position.
The information bar just bellow the menu Actions shows the complete Flow tree of the selected Flow.

section.title: Coping, pasting and deleting programs
section.para:
In the same manner we can copy and paste Flows (see ), a program (or set of programs) can be copied to the clipboard by clicking
or by using the shortcut
Ctrl C .

To remove a program (or set of programs), select them and click on
.

tip.para:
You can deal with several programs at once by holding
Ctrl Click or
Shift Click .

A program (or set of programs) that have been copied to the clipboard can be pasted any Flow, and not just the Flow of origin. Simply switch to the Flows tab, select the target Flow, go back to the Flow editor tab and paste the program(s).

caution.para: GêBR does not ask for confirmation before deleting programs from a Flow.

section.title: Editing program's parameters
section.para: Program's parameters compose a set of initial configurations defined by the user.
To edit program's parameters:

step.para:
Select the program from the Flow sequence box and click on
on the toolbar, or just double-click on the program. The Parameter dialog box will appear.
Edit the program's parameters. Notice that each program's parameter vary greatly both in size and type.

tip.para: Click on the Help button (bottom left corner of the dialog box) to view the program's documentation. This will be certainly useful when you are editing the programs parameters.
Click on the Default button when you want the program to return to its default configurations.

step.para: When you are done click on the OK button.

section.title: Changing a program's state
section.para:
After you have carried out process of , the icon beside the program will change from
to
. This means that the program's state passed from Not configured to the Configured state. Besides these two states, the program can also be set to the Disabled state (
). You can alternate between these states by using two methods, you can either right-click on the program and then select from the context menu the desired state, or by using the shortcut
Spacebar to change the state(s) of the selected programs.

tip.para:
You can select several programs whose state you wish to change by holding
Ctrl Click or
Shift Click .
Changing a program state does not alter its parameter configuration. You can safely alternate between states.

important.para:
Disabled programs (
) will be ignored when you execute your Flow. With this you can enable and disable parts of your Flow.

section.title: Editing the Flow's input and output files
section.para: How to associate an input, output and error file to a Flow:

mediaobject.caption: Select the Flow Editor Tab, in the Flow sequence box you can edit the input, output and log files for this Flow sequence.

step.para: Selecte a Flow, in the Flow tab, and switch to the Flow Editor tab.
In the Flow sequence box, you can edit the input, output and log files paths by double clicking on them.

section.para: If you want to use the folders associated to your Line, you can either choose like above or you can use the feature of autocomplete of the important folders of this Line.

mediaobject.caption: Autocomplete feature in the Input file of a Flow.

section.para:
When you choose a path for your Flow's input/output, their file paths will appear in the Flow sequence box, indicated by the icons
and
, below and above the Flow's programs (if there are any).

note.para: If you wish to remove a set from the list, select them by pressing right-click then click on Exclude.

section.title: Executing a Flow
section.para:
To execute the current Flow click on
. Or using the tab Flows (check ).

In the Flow Editor Tab, you can execute a Flow after another Flow, creating a queue of execution. To execute after a specific Flow, instead of executing "Immediately", switch to the Flow Editor Tab and choose the "After Flow A".
By default, the Flows are executed on the Maestro group. More details on the definition and selection of servers and groups of servers can be found in .

In the Flow Editor tab, even if you have selected several Flows from the Flows tab, when you click on
, only the first of the selected Flows will be executed.

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of the Flow Editor tab. In the first menu of the Run, you can choose after which flow it will be executed.

section.para: At the moment the Flow is executed, GêBR automatically switches to the Job Control tab and displays a report of the execution of the Flow .

section.title: Executing a Flow multiple times
section.para: The program LoopLoop (from the category Loops) has a totally different usage compared to the remaining programs from GêBR. We are going to see some of these differences.

When we add the program Loop, we can see it always appears in the top of the Flow. That happens to indicate that the Flow is going to be executed more than once, according to the parameters set for the program. (see for further details).

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of program Loop, added to a Flow and properly configured.

section.para: After the Loop is added, you have access to a new variable, the iter (see ). The value of this special variable is modified on each iteration (increasing or decrementing), according to the parameters set.

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of the edition from parameters of Loop program, with a simple example of parameters setting.

section.title: Multiple machines
section.para: If GêBR is connected to multiple machines through the Servers Configuration interface, and the selected Flow is parallelizableFlowparallelizable (see below the criteria to be parallelizable), then you have the option to run in a distributed way.
To be considered parallelizable, besides having a loop, a Flow must achieve one of these criteria:

listitem.para: The Flow does not have an output file;
The output of each step of the loop is not the input of any other step of the loop.

section.para: In case the Flow is not parallelizable (i.e., does not fit one of the above conditions), GêBR will run the job in the best machine at the time of execution (GêBR rank them based mainly in availability and speed). In a distributed execution, it may be important to differentiate the Priority mode. When the Flow is parallelizable, it is the split up and distributed between the available machines according to their ranking.
If you want to run a Flow in a specified machine, then he can force the execution by going to Flow Editor tab, as choosing the working machine as shown below.
